	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Wouldn't it be simpler to just specify some heat transfer properties  
for the wall?

I think if you manually change the gas state, then it might be  
necessary to start over, creating new reactor objects, etc., each  
time. Calling "reinitialize" (which simply calls the "reinitialize"  
procedure of the CVODE integrator) should work in principle, but in  
my experience it doesn't always.


Best wishes,
Dave


On May 24, 2007, at 1:31 AM, Daniele Chiappini wrote:

> avmokhov ha scritto:
>> Daniele,
>>
>> It seems for me that the most probable reason for this behavior is
>> that you changed the thermodynamic properties of some components in
>> such a way that you actually have frozen your system. In other words,
>> with new thermodynamic properties your system is already in
>> equilibrium and therefore, does not change with time. To test this,
>> try to change the thermodynamic properties very gradually and look
>> what will happen. Other possibilities such as very small time step,
>> wrong reinitialization of an object etc. could not be excluded  
>> though.
>>
>> Best regards, Anatoli.
>>
>> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "dottorato82" <daniele.chiappini@...>
>> wrote:
>> >
>> > Hi to all,
>> > I would like to simulate a combustion process in a piston and I've
>> > already simulated it like a reactor with a moving wall obtaining
>> good
>> > results. However, I am now trying to simulate the combustion  
>> process
>> > with a series of adiabatic reactors because I need to do some
>> > operations on the thermodynamic properties between two timestps. At
>> > the end of every timestep I save variables like gas temperature,
>> > pressure and composition and, after doing what I need to do, I
>> > re-initialize a new reactor with the initial conditions which I've
>> > computed. Doing it I've encountered a big problem: the reactor
>> afeter
>> > the first timesetp doesn't evaluate the chemestry in it. In other
>> > words it modifies the composition of the mixture only in the first
>> > timestep, during the others it doesn't do anything regarding the
>> > reactions in it so I cannot evaluate the correct behavior of the  
>> gas
>> > during the compression and expansion strokes.
>> > Somebody has ideas or suggestions about it?
>> > Thank you very much for your help and your willingness.
>> >
>> > Daniele
>> >
>>
>>
> Dear Anatoli,
>
> I think that I have to explain better my problem.  I would  
> implement heat transfer in a simulation of a piston. I've chosen to  
> implement a reactor with constant volume and I simulate it in a  
> ReactorNet  for every timestep. After every iteration I save the  
> value of the composition and I operate on temperature and pressure  
> levels. At the end I upgrade the gas state with the new value of  
> temperature, pressure and composition. Of course I reinitialize the  
> reactor and the reactornet with the instruction r.initialize()  and  
> I change the volume of the reactor with the new one. The strange  
> thing is that the reactor should solve evaluate the chemistry but  
> it doesn't, I know that levels of temperature and pressure require  
> these reactions.
> Thank you for your attention.
>
> Daniele
> 


--Apple-Mail-4--160116654
